title: Supporting Each Other's Goals
description: Explore how you support each other's personal growth and aspirations.

questions.text: When it comes to supporting my partner's goals, I naturally tend to...
choices: Offer encouragement and believe in them
Help with practical steps and actions
Give them space to figure it out
Join them and do it together

therapeutic.rationale: How we support our partner's goals reflects our love language and attachment style. Encouragers offer emotional support; helpers offer practical action; space-givers respect autonomy; joiners create shared experience. Giving the wrong kind of support can feel unsupportive despite good intentions.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different support styles can frustrate. The encouragement-wanter may feel the helper is trying to take over; the space-needer may feel the joiner is intruding. Ask: 'What kind of support would help you most?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared support styles mean you'll naturally give each other what works. You understand because it's what you'd want too.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you naturally support your partner? Is that what they actually need?

questions.text: The best way my partner can support my personal goals is by...
choices: Believing in me and saying so
Helping me stay accountable
Giving me time and space to work on them
Being interested and asking about my progress

therapeutic.rationale: Knowing what support you need—and communicating it—prevents the common pattern of partners trying hard but missing the mark. Belief-needers want faith; accountability-needers want structure; space-needers want autonomy; interest-needers want engagement.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different support needs require adaptation. Your partner may not intuitively know what you need—tell them explicitly.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched support needs make helping each other natural. You instinctively give what your partner wants.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What support from your partner would most help your goals? Have you asked for it?

questions.text: When my partner is working toward something important, I feel...
choices: Proud and excited for them
Eager to help however I can
Happy to give them the space they need
A little left out if I'm not involved

therapeutic.rationale: How we feel about our partner's independent pursuits reveals attachment patterns. Pride shows secure support; eagerness shows involvement desire; space-giving shows respect for autonomy; feeling left out shows connection needs. All are understandable reactions.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The left-out feeler may need more inclusion; the space-giver may need to remember to connect. Balance supporting independence with maintaining connection.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared feelings about partner goals create aligned expectations about involvement during growth pursuits.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when your partner is focused on their own goals? What do you need during those times?

questions.text: In our relationship, personal goals should be...
choices: Fully supported even if they don't involve us
Balanced with time for the relationship
Shared when possible, individual when needed
Discussed together before committing

therapeutic.rationale: Beliefs about individual vs. couple goals shape how you navigate growth. Full-supporters prioritize individual flourishing; balancers protect relationship time; sharers seek overlap; discussers want partnership in decisions. Misaligned beliefs cause tension.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different philosophies need negotiation. The full-supporter may feel the discusser is controlling; the discusser may feel the full-supporter is disconnected. Find your shared approach.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared philosophy about personal goals makes navigating individual growth easier.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What role should individual goals play in your relationship? How do you balance self and us?

questions.text: I'd love for us to grow together by...
choices: Pursuing shared goals and dreams
Supporting each other's individual paths
Learning and trying new things together
Becoming better partners to each other

therapeutic.rationale: Growth visions reveal what you want your relationship to become. Shared-goal seekers want joint pursuits; individual-supporters want mutual flourishing; learners want novelty; better-partners want relationship improvement. Naming your vision helps you pursue it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different growth visions can all be pursued—they're not mutually exclusive. Discuss which feels most important right now.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared growth vision aligns your development as a couple. You're aiming for the same future.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What does growing together look like to you? What would make your relationship even better?
